title: Is this grammatically correct? There are three twos (for 2 2 2). - Quora

response.answer_text: Your sentence is grammatically correct as it stands. However as the context isn’t clear from the sentence, it’s natural if we’re a little concerned about whether this would be the usual way to express your meaning in that context. As Ms Iyer correctly says, if this is part of a telephone number or an address or any kind, it is essential to be clear. However no native speaker would say “The numerical digit ‘2’ is repeated thrice”. Although correct, it’s terribly long-winded and over-formal.If the number is, for example, 01673 222 7345, I would say ‘oh one six seven three, triple two, seven three four five’. If questioned I’d say “Yes, there are three twos; two two two.” On the other hand if you were writing your sentence, it would be clearer if you wrote “There are three 2s”.

“There are three number twos” would be more clear linguistically. However, our language is beautiful in that there are many ways to convey the same thought. What truly matters in this instance is whether or not your audience comprehends the message as you intend it to be understood. If your question concerned the use of an apostrophe for the plural of two, that rule is generally only true if the plural of a numeral or of a letter are used (e.g. 2’s, E's). One common saying that creates some confusion to this rule is “Two's a couple, Three's a crowd”, but the reason for this is the 's serve as contractions in place of “two is” and “three is”.

I find no mistake with this sentence. I suspect you really are asking about the spelling. It used to be advised for a time to use an apostrophe with all plurals of numbers and letters. The advice did not hold up against logic, however, and now most authorities advise simply adding s except where confusion might result, as in “How many as are in the following sentence.” As a young reader, I was puzzled for a while with the phrase “count by twos" in Land of Oz, a UK publication from the 20s, to give you some historical data.

Please speak giving similar space.

“There are three twos.” - yes, this is grammatically fine. Some people would put an apostrophe before the ‘s’ on the end of ‘twos’ - this is a mistake. To quote The Oxford Guide to Style, “Do not use the apostrophe when creating plurals. This includes names, abbreviations … numbers, and words not usually used as nouns [example of the correct way to do it]: … sixes and sevens …”.

That is the sentence that can be said, but cannot be written. Chose one: There are three TOs in English. (To, To & To?) There are three TOOs in English. (Too, Too, Too?) There are three TWOs in English. (Two, Two, Two?) You lose, all are wrong. You cannot write: There are three T____s in English. (To, Too, Two)
